title: 114_s1990
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Computer Security Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The "Federal Computer Security Act" defines key terms such as agency, covered agency, logical access control, and multi-factor logical access controls for Federal computer systems. An Inspector General report on Federal computer systems is also required. Inspector Generals of covered agencies must submit a report to the Comptroller General and relevant committees within 240 days of the Act's enactment. The report should include information on logical access standards for Federal computer systems, including a list and description of access controls used and whether multi-factor controls are in place. The report required by the Act must include details on logical access controls for Federal computer systems, such as a list and description of controls used and whether multi-factor controls are implemented. Additionally, it should cover data security management practices, including software inventories and licensing procedures. The covered agency's practices include conducting software inventories, entering into licensing agreements for software security controls, and describing how the software is used. If the agency does not use certain software, reasons for not doing so must be provided. The report required under this section includes a description of the covered agency's policies for ensuring data security practices among entities providing services, and may be based on existing audits or evaluations. The report can be unclassified but may have a classified annex, and must be available to Members of Congress upon request. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, analyzing impediments to agency use of security software and devices. The report may include a classified annex but will be in unclassified form.
